If you refuse, then the alien's attitude toward you is immediately 100% hostile, and remains that way for the rest of the game until you annihilate them in blinding fire.

They will become scared of you when you outpace them, but they'll still hate you and, even if they drop out of war with you temporarily due to other conflicts, they will always re-declare war with you in due course (even if you have no further direct interaction). In fact, they'll choose to remain at war with you even when you have obliterated every colony they possess and you are currently hanging over their home planet in a massive fleet with your finger poised on the 'exterminate' button - rather than yielding to the inevitable and grudgingly accepting a Peace Treaty.

All the races are the same in this respect and none of the native characteristics make any difference or show through in any manner other than in voice acting. E.g. the humans are intended to be diplomats and the Psilons explorers (generalising), yet they both (like all the races) become immediately upset if you decline to share charts and then, upon refusal of the next request (usually of cash, tech and conceding a system) become enraged and declare war. Is it possible to elicit any different relationship progression or behaviour from them? Yes, but only by playing such an absurdly exaggerated game style that it makes it not only ridiculous and unenjoyable, but completely self-defeating. There is no realistic possibility of diplomacy or subtlety. In summary, the AI is completely common to all races, with only the voice acting attempting to be a differentiator.

MOO fans (of which I am one) are going to point out that divergent AI was never a strong suit of MOO races, or indeed any 4x game out there - and they'd be right - but this is a really obvious short-falling (or opportunity in waiting), particularly so because the way the races have been portrayed and brought to life by voice acting gives the expectation that they are actually going to be interestingly and amusingly different in game play. The devs have a great opportunity here to make this a stand-out aspect of the game.

I will be mostly playing multiplayer, as PVP is really what I enjoy, but of all games, I want to enjoy the AI and distinct racial attributes, quirkiness and game play that MOO can offer. I am optimistic that this will be forthcoming, as I am pretty certain the team is determined to make this something special.I am still enjoying the game and will wait to see how things develop.

Cheers

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Keep in mind, at the time of this writing it is still in early access and a lot of finished features aren't complete.

Initial impressions: I like how this beta felt pretty polished from the beginning. They have a great base game the feels like the old masters of orion. The system is easy to follow, A lot of the old research technologies were there. I would have liked to see some more tech however. I felt it was a good start of a tech tree, however playing different races didn't feel different. Asside from the ships looking different, that was about it.  As of this writing I have only played psilon and humans.

What I would like to see improve: Ship combat in this game is kinda weak. I didn't feel there was much strategy to it other than ship priority. The real time combat system made it feel like picking priority targets was pretty much all you could do. I miss the turn based combat myself. The models look amazing though!

I haven't read what the developers are going to do yet, and what hasn't been implemented. Some things I never found like spying for example. I felt the diplomacy section was a bit lacking as I couldn't select some colonies or techs.

This game has great potential and I am looking forward to seeing what they do to improve it. However as it is right now its little more than a remake of the origional Master of Orion and little else.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nJust finished my first game.  I played as the Mrrrshan and was able to dominate via technology building and generally staying out of the computer players way during expansion.  It was fun!  I liked the tech tree - I was able to get to titan level ships, class V shields, phasors, battle pods, plus all the supporting economic tools.  I found that my tech rate was outstripping my ability upgrade battleships - most of my cruisers (and smaller ships) were quite capable and easily maintained with every upgrade.  The battleships not so much and I didn't even get a single titan built - started several, but I won by having the votes due to my population being about 3-4x higher than the computer players.  I may have coerced all the other players to vote for me with a yearly annuity of 20 BC (except the #2 sized player).  It played well over steam link with the keyboard and mouse configuration for the steam controller.   I found that a 35 TV made the text a bit small from across the room.  I eventually finished the game on my PC directly and enjoyed being able to read all the text quite clearly."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an interesting and rather good reboot of the original Master of Orion. This was one of the first 4X games I ever played and enjoyed, and this reboot lives up to the original feel. The game play can be a little buggy at times, but it’s still in development.
All the original races are brought to life, they interact better with the new advances that AIs have made since the original MOO came out and it makes the game enjoyable by actually having challenges between the races.

+The voice acting is an added benefit, not a something at I would say is the reason to play but a nice bonus.

+The HUD is simple, yet detailed enough to understand and find the data you need.

+Technology is broken down into trees that you have to make some choices to advance, and it allows a deeper level of strategy planning into the sciences.

+Graphics are definitely better, and are still based on the core of the original game. The ships are better designed for racial visuals and they also allow for a more customized look at each race compared to original MOO.

-Diplomacy is a little buggy, and could use work to balance it out.

-The News is more annoying than in past games.

Other than a few bugs here and there, the game is awesome. I would highly recommend that you buy and play if you are a fan of the original. This is a good re-boot of the original Master of Orion from nearly 20 years ago.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off I recommend this game based on the potential it clearly has to be a classic turn based strategy / 4x space game. If the developers put some manhours into this thing it can be great, right now it's just good - and in alpha of course.

The gameplay right now is fine and I haven't noticed any bugs - This is a pleasant surprise. The galaxy map is set up to pen you in and make you wait for technologies or fight your way out, Read starlanes, dead ends, unstable / unusable starlanes and space bases that block passage unless you have open borders. Conversely you can use these features of the game to quickly pen an opponent in to a small area and keep them weak.

The tech tree and planetary screens are easy to understand and use, although there is a weird quirk in the tech tree: Some technologies you research have two different upgrades on them but by reasearching the tech you only get to pick one of the upgrades, the other is forever excluded from you. Perhaps they intend you to get them through espionage or maybe it's just supposed to make everybody's tech a little different. Either way it's weird but interesting and I'll have to see how I like it after a while.  Upgrading ships is easy, a single click upgrades the design with the latest goodies and a single click upgrades existing ships that are in orbit of a planet you own.

By far my biggest complaint is just the visual appeal of the game. It's absolutely awful. Everything is black and dark and two dimensional. Yes space is black but space is also amazingly colorful and beutiful. For god's sake wargaming, choose the colorful and beautiful, not the black; for example you can click on your planet to get an overall view of what it's doing, guess what, 4/5ths of your planet is covered in night (facepalm). And get rid of the two dimensional feel! For example, you can click on buildings on your planet, like a marine barracks and all that happens is a small tooltip comes up with a crappy two dimensional image of the barracks and a paragraph about what it does. How about bringing me to a 3 dimensional barracks with soldiers and tanks running around and letting me look inside multiple buildings and talk to advisors in those buildings? This game has too much potential to be so visually and auditorilly boring that people may not be able to sit through 100 turns.

I still recommend the game but beware of the boredom if you like your games to give you a feast for your eyes and ears.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bottom line: 4 hours went by just disappeared like it did when I turned on MoO1 for the first time. Mission accomplished, team. I've played MoO and MoO2 for the same 20 years that I imagine most fans have played it. When GoG made it available, it is one of those moments when the clouds parted and a ray of sunshine definitely showed through. I think the best thing we can all say about MoO3 is to not talk about it, except for the lessons about detail and colony management that were probably taken into account with this edition.

Die-hards already know alot of the changes: new in-depth and awesome backstories for each fo the races, updated visuals that are beyond words awesome, clean crisp interface that combines the simplicty of MoO with the needs of MoO2. But the new is also means starlanes, no turn by turn tactical combat (yet?), race characteristics tweakability not what we're used to and a few other limitations.

It's so clear that the team put so much love into this and that early access is where we the fans get to provide input now that if only we could have done with MoO3 could've changed our feelings from disdain to reverence. This MoO is beautiful, sounds like the original with updated music, and the visual RTS tactical combat made me swear up and down when I didn't do it in tactical when my major Psilon fleet went up again the Bulrathe (and lost of course).

It's not meant to be a clone of the originals. We can play those anytime we want now. But as a long-time fan, EA is worth it to see it, play it, and give suggestions on how to improve it.

New to the franchise, maybe you should wait for an even more polished copy at release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is early access, and it shows. It has its ups and downs. Despite my short play time, I have a list of positives and negatives. Edits will come as the game is rolled out further.

March 31st updates---

Positives:
+Better balancing of gameplay.
+Diplomacy now functions properly.
+Klackon, Meklar, and Terran added.
+Technological victory added.

Negatives:
-Meklar are massively overpowered in research.
-Terran have major environmental issues.
-Spies not implemented.



(Original Alpha release comments below)
Positives:
+Very good looking reboot of an excellent 4x game.
+Easy to play, and intuitive.
+Extremely stable, I have had no instances of lag whatsoever.
+It's as addictive as it should be.
+Excellent voice acting, audio, and music.

Negatives:
-Racial implementation is incomplete, several races not implemented yet.*
-Diplomacy needs work. Wars are next to impossible to get out of short of total genocide.
-No spies or espionage implemented yet. I suspect that the Darloks will be released with spies.*
-Combat needs balancing, it's like a less effective combat system from MoO 3. ~see additional comments.
-Ship design feels far more limited than previous Master of Orion games.
-Random events need to be balanced. Every one I have seen has been a planet's mineral classification increasing.
-Star systems need better balancing. Most systems are 2-3 objects orbiting the star, a (very) few have 5.
-Techs sometimes force you to choose between two things AFTER the research is complete. I experienced this several times before I finally noticed there is a bar between the icons in the research box. This needs to be clarified. I like the idea of having to branch research in some areas one way or another, but the choice should be when the research is beginning, not when it has concluded. ~see additional comments for furtherance.

Additional comments:
~Cannot rename stars and planets!!!!! --This drove me crazy with MoO 3 until it was patched.
~Cannot choose flag colour. --This also was an issue with MoO 3 before patching.
~Run spellcheck, there are several spelling errors throughout the game.
~Real time combat can  be nice, but MoO had very well balanced turn based combat before 3. Why not have a setting for turn based combat as well as real time?
~It might also be nice to branch the techs out further with the choosing specific research areas. With Fusion, if you choose fusion beam, you should get later research for enhanced targeting computers, if you go with fusion bombs, you should have later research options for hardened colony structures, or another defencive area for planets.

*Annoying, but it's early access, and these will be put in. I look forward to the full release!

New content coming out for this quite regularly, really captures the feel of the old game. It's great but beware - it's being sold as a full price game and it isn't quite there yet. There are a few bugs, for example - spying, a new mechanic they recently implemented. It used to be one of my favourite mechanics about the Darlok race but it just doesn't really work at the moment (the game keeps saying I stole a Class I Shield, this has happened about 20 times .. yet I still didn't even get it - kinda defeated the point of the race xD).

That said, it is early access as it states above. This kind of stuff is to be expected and the game is still really fun even at this early kinda buggy stage - so long as you can work around the bugs ( No Darlok race for me just yet :( )

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Keeping in mind that this is early access, I really like this game already. I never played the original games so I don't really care about the changes as long as this game is fun. It seems most of the negative reviews are coming from fans of the originals and I can understand, but I judge the game as is without the nostalgia baggage.

The game has a polished look and feel to it but it is also missing a lot of features and depth (AI should be better, diplomacy is not great and the game is way to easy). They really nailed the UI and design of the overall game. Some minor bugs with numbers and text, but that is to be expected. I really hope this game will be fully fleshed out and I hope it will be a great game. Normally I dislike EA and almost never participate, but after watching some youtubers play this game I was swayed and don't regret it.

It already is fun, but it needs more work to become a great game. I am optimistic.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Like many others, I grew up with Master of Orion 1 and 2 and (after the dissapointing MoO 3) waited for a very long time for a worthy sequel.

So far, Master of Orion looks that it might be that sequel, though given that its early access, it is too early to tell for sure.

Right from the start, the game feels very familiar to a veteran MoO 2 player. You can tell that this game was made by people who know and love the MoO franchise. Most changes made to gameplay (like starlanes) are minor in nature and, at least in my opinion, make sense. The ship designer in particular is still there and not too different from MoO 2  (You can still outfit you ships with tons of different weapons and specials, as well as modify the weapons themselves - missles, beam weapons, point defense, firing arcs, ecm jammers, fighter / bomber bays, you name it).

The only real big change is the - much discussed - replacement of the turn based space combat with a (pauseable) real time version. While I am not to stoked about this myself, I do not think this is the end world, and - if done right - might even a good thing. Unfortunately, given that the A.I. is very limted so far in Early Access (the A.I.  difficulty is set to average for now), I have not been able to experience any battle involving two large fleets so far, where you could truly test the depth of the real time combat system.

Just to be clear (because I have seen wrong information about this), the combat is not merely a interactive movie, like (unfortuantely) in games like Endless Space. You have full control over the ships, i.e. you can designate targets, maneuver the ships and manually activate specials on the ships.

Anyhow, whether you think that MoO is a worthy sequel or not, it at the very least looks to have the potential to be an excellent 4X game,

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI bought this game about 48 hrs ago , spent large part of yesterday afternoon playing it , for an early access game played very well , only had it freeze up 2 times when combat completed - I played MOO2 ,and liked it , but I like this one better , have seen some complaints that it was not a remake of MOO1 and MOO2 , I personly really like this game , that said , I got MOO1 , MOO2 , and MOO3 free as a bonus when i purchased this game while in early access , a great deal . - it does of course need some work I played as nature loving bears at default difficulty , i managed to get a jump on all the other empires/civs in game by quickly exploring and grabbing 2 or 3 key star sytems  , colonizing said systems 1st , fortifying the outbound routes from my territory , and placing warships there ASAP - then after the fact sending out colonization ships to the many planets i bypassed while seizing those key systems - I have the largest economy , largest tech and largest military  and while I am not liked none dare to attack me since I have 2 large and powerful fleets at each end of my empire - I am not really that good at these games so I suspect I either just got very lucky and got the jump on the other races by grabbing key systems or the balancing and or AI need more work - ALL IN ALL A VERY GOOD GAME LOOKING FORWARD TO THEM COMPLETEING IT .

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I barely played 2 hours, but here is what I got from the game:

It's very fun, It's a very interesting game, especially for a fan of the Civilization games. It has that feel to it of managing resources, income and maintenance that feels like a galactic based Civ game. And just like in Civ, I suck at this game aswell.

Battles are fun, even while being Real-Time. The whole universe looks very cool and engaging. The game really makes you want to explore the universe.

It runs good, not excelent, not bad. Although for some reason, the graphics seem to be kinda lackluster and there is no real difference between the 3 best options, plus there isn't a custom graphic configuration.

The things I didn't like:
The fact that I'm restricted until well into the game to really explore the universe. I'm limited by those warp thingies that can't be crossed until a fairly advanced tech is researched.

AI is SH¡T overly agressive, I colonized a planet that another race didn't even explore yet, they are mad and they declared war already. Minutes after starting the game.

It should be clear from the get go how does the planet's characteristics affect your race and your colonies, which makes for bad mistakes that can ruin a game.

Plus, some VERY important info, such as a planet's gravity, can't be seen in uncolonized planets unless you close the overview and go to the full list of planets you discovered. Inconvinient at best.

I guess my biggest issue with this game is the BLATANT LACK OF EXPLANATION. Nothing is clearly stated, which can mess up real bad a game. Just because you have to go the extra mile just to know something so basic as to how to establish a trading rout. Ships automatically jump straight to the enemy's face unless you're really quick and prevent them from doing. It kinda takes away my strategic skills if on RTS the ships automatically jump to their deaths.

Land invations are ♥♥♥♥, no further question. That should need a MASSIVE rework.

Despite all these issues, the game is really fun. I highly recommend this game. But it is true that the game is still kinda green". There is a lot that needs to be implemented. But I have faith it will be very good as a final product."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

CAVEAT: Early Access.

This iteration of MOO has the feel. It has the lore. Some of the animations and voice acting (particular the Psilon) is a little cartoony, but nothing too annoying.

The mechanics are solid, the graphics are great, and the AI is very wimpy and needs serious work. Combat is good although I warn you it is not turn based, which presents both new opportunities but also requires you to rethink how you do combat.

Ship design is a bit less robust in someways -- since you fight in RT trick ships with teleporting boarding shuttle loads are not as effective.

The stellar converter is still there. So are doom stars.

Right now, I give it a 6/10. I think there's room for improvement, but I also think based on what I see that improvements will happen. Most importantly, no crashes and no bugs encountered (by me at least, I can't speak for others.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off I am an old school gamer. I loved MOO and MOO2. Would not wipe a convicts ♥♥♥ with MOO3.  Ok that being said

I want to love this. The game is getting a very nice polish after years ont he shelf. But LIke XCOM you CAN NOT TAKE THE SAME GAME and just update the Graphics. The Reason XCOM reboot worked is becuase they made it thier own. it brought the familiar and added enough new to make it great. I want the same thing here very bad.

Pros.
1. Graphics and Sound are top notch. - the voice acting is spectautlar and if you are a geek like me most of the voices will be familer to you. (see things like Firefly and STNG). The graphics show real polish. the detail on the GUI and tactical maps are scary good.
2. Stable--ish - some poeple are saying they did not have crash issues. I hit a few bugs in my playthorughs both single and multi-player. Forcing me to reload the turn ( thank god for Autosave). But other than that smooth.

Cons-

1. Ok easy one first. Labels and discriptions.  Many times. the discriptions were not accurate enough.  For example. When you are resarching a beam weapon on the tech tree you get that weapons damage, size, and cost.  Then you get to the Ship design Screen... and all you get is an inaccurate DPS and a frustating 'fleet value' more on that later.   Another example, is the Jumpgate discription... all you get is this helps you travel between your colonies faster..." that's it.. nothing else. It doesn't actually say that it will let you travel Directly between 2 colonies without using the warp lanes. A better discription here would have made me jump on the tech much sooner in my first time through ( I obviously did in subsiquent playthroughs)

2. Ship Design in general- The ship design screen is problably my biggest headache. Small bugs like the "this ship is already being used.  to the 'Auto' update that actually overwrites your ship designs with less efficeint weapons and even older armors and computers.."

3. Tactical Combat- And here we have it. the ONE thing that NO 4x game seems to get right except MOO and MOO2(and even they had some flaws). Real time combat in this game is point and click you have no control over most weapons.  This problem was solved in MOO2 by a simple "on"/"off" switch. The asteroids do offer a SMALL amount of stratagy. you can use them to hide ship and engage on close combat
date: but that is a crap shoot and most weapons seem to go around or over them
recommended:
Honestly the only truly great 3D realtime space combat I have seen is Homeworld. Soo unless you can steel a game engine or two I would suggest a switch back to turnbased. (might not be possible.. but hey I can dream)

4. ok lastly  Warp lanes- Lets get one thing straight I LIKE the idea of warp lanes they segment the galaxy and it makes empire building interesting. Especially because you cannot jump through all of them right away and there is tech (jumpgates) that negates the lanes somewhat. THIS IS A GOOD THING. you can build the defense stations to give your empire a true 'border' without having sentries at every single frikken one of your colonies.

What I do not like about them is that they are BOTHnNot limiting enough and it takes to damn long to just use them. First you have to spend a whole turn to get to the point
hoursPlayed:
Then you send X number of turns traveling through the lane then you Finnaly reach the destination and it starts all over.  In the early game I would expect this kind of limitation but I would also expect Techs to negate the flaws.

For example.. All ships no matter the tech are only able to move ONE spot in a system a turn.. Better engines/fuel cells should allow for more mobility..  And the final engine in previous games allowed for instantanious travel between systems. ( Warp Gates and Transwarp drives).

Ok that covers the time it takes to use them now the  "not limiting enough" you can LITERALY SCOUT the ENTIRE GALAXY no matter what tech lvl you are. As I said before there are some warp lanes you cannot travel through
voteText: but it just doesn't feel epic when you can see and speak to every single race in the first 50 turns... I miss the limiters that  pushed you to research better fuel Cells so you could get that xtra parsec.\n\nOn the whole I would say this game is a GREAT alpha. I hope beyond hope that some of the issues above will be solved before release and I am looking forward to seeing the final product."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, Master of Orion (Or MoO for short) is a 4X turn based strategy game. This game however, is a reboot of the series. This game bears little resemblance to the older games, despite the title. I personally believe that you should not review a game based on your love for the previous games. With that in mind, I will be giving this game a full non-bias review.

When I saw this game, it was an immediate buy. It is being made by WarGaming, the same creators of World of Tanks, World of Warplanes, and World of Warships. They have been working their behinds off on those games for years, so when I saw this, I knew they would have a short early access period for it. As of the time of this review, it has had no updates. The next update is scheduled to be very soon.

They have stated that they are going to change much of the game. They have listened to their community and are addressing issues that people have. They are adding new races, making races more unique, slowing the speed at which you get new ships, and various other things. I know that most of you are thinking. WHAT ABOUT THE DARN STAR LANES?!!!!!" Well
date: they said they will never remove them. They have stated that if they didn't put star lanes in the game
recommended: the AI would be exploited far too easily. They have said that they may add an option to travel to a system without the use of star lanes through a late game technology
hoursPlayed: but the travel would be very slow. They are also working on difficulty levels for the AI. Espionage is missing at the moment.\n\nNow for the good stuff
voteText: the game itself. The game is very addicting. You get a similar feeling to playing Civilization 5. However I feel that this game's pacing is too fast. You are forced to colonize every planet as fast as possible or get left in the dust. Everyone expands far too quickly
helpfulPercent: as there is no penalty for doing so. Once you learn that
votesHelpful: you are golden. A guarenteed win every game. The AI is as dumb as a sack of rocks. But
votesTotal: that's why it's early access. More difficulties coming soon!(Hopefully). The AI mass up their armies of low tier ships as I get my Doom Star and Titans fitted up for war. Then came the final battle. 5 Titans and 1 Doom Star against 50 destroyers and 28 Frigates. SERIOUSLY???? That's pathetic. At least build some bigger ships or something. That's like the US army versus an ancient African tribe.\n\nThe planets and seiging need lots of work. The planets need to look more different. Every planet of one type will look exactly the same. The sieging is just explosions. There needs to be ships surrounding the planet
votesFunny: and craters left from the bombs. The terraforming is amazing
commentsCount: but you can't terraform planets that already have a bad environment. You should at least be able to terraform any planet
column16: but if the environment is bad it should just take longer. The pollution system is very cool
column17: and makes you have to take some very hard decisions. Example: Do I want to finish the production of my Titan and permanently damage my planet's ecosystem
column18: or stop production and do some pollution clean up?\n\nThe tactical battle lack depth. I feel like I'm just a spectator
column19: rather than a commander that my army is relying on to win the battle. The ships just charge each other like a bunch of barbarians. The abilities are essentially useless. The only useful ability is the black hole generator
column20: which sucks ships in and does massive amount of damage.\n\nThe races also lack depth. The only thing that really separates them is the look of their ships. They need specific traits and unique ships/buildings
column21: like in Civ 5. I also feel a need for race specific technologies.\n\nSCORE: 6/10 - slightly above average. The game is missing depths and uniqueness
column22: but is still very fun to play."

I, for one, recommend this game in this phase for the vibrant (well, vibrant for a 4x means you can get games together with 4-8 players on a regular basis) multiplayer scene.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIt's just crap right now.  All the money wasted on voice acting should have went into making an actual game that isn't horrid.   This game is nowhere near as interesting or as well put together as Master of Orion 2.  Starlanes are horrible idea, there is no sense of exploration when your starting scouts can visit every single star system without comming back to refuel or anything.  Monsters guard individual planets, not systems, so you don't have to worry about anything at all and map the whole galaxy.  Diplomacy is a joke,  you have to spend money to make trade agreements that don't last more than 20 turns....WTF?  In Master of orion 2, if you could actually get a treaty going,  you were rewarded with that treaty until you Messed up, or got framed for stealing a Tech that you really didn't do, that's fine.... buy why spend hundreds of credits on a treaty that wont even give you the money back that it cost you to set up before it runs out?  Stupid and pointless.  Espionage is pointless because everyone gets every tech, what is the point in wasting time stealing something that you are going to get anyway?   In Master of Orion 2 you HAD to spy if you wanted to get some of the good stuff that you HAD to pass on to get something else that was Indespensable.  Diplomacy animations cannot be disabled at this time, you have to wade through listening to crap that is pointless, the best strategy I found was not ever research the tech that let you establish an embasy so you don't have to listen to drivel.  No Turned based Combat is a total deal breaker,  the real time tactical combat is so boring and pointless and such a small 2D arena, I really don't understand why the Master of Orion 2 model of combat can't be used, I mean, the combat arena in Orion 2 is bigger!  SAD.  Overall, if you liked Orion 2,  keep playing Orion 2.  This game isn't even as good as Master of Orion 3, which is just about the biggest insult I can give to any game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I dont reccomend buying this until it gets finished...and only then when it gets a big discount.
It looks good, but gets stale quite fast.
It's basically a dumbed-down version of master of orion2, with alot less freedom to mold the galaxy as you see fit.
For example, i just conquored a klackon planet...i dont like those bugs and i want to erradicate the bug population, and move my human colonists to the planet and use the existing structures. But i cant do that, i must assimilate them into my empire. The only way to get rid of the bugs is to completely destroy the klackon base, including all the structures, then build a new base with my colony ship.
Also, the space combat is really bad.
And there is really no sense of exploration...it's very linear, you can only follow space-lanes to other planets.
I played alot of master of orion 1 and 2, and i'm quite disappointed...this could have been awesome, but sadly it is mediocre at best.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The thing to understand before you buy is that this is not a finished game or beta test.

The game is currently in Alpha, the phase of development where the prototype is fuctional but major features are not compleate or even notationaly in the software yet. This means that, as it stands, the game can be played start to finish but major parts are missing (spying, several races, ect)

Other parts are implemented, but unfinished. Combat is currently playable, but has the hallmarks of a placeholder that will be barely recongizable at release. Many planet discriptions and technologies are likewise placeholders that are likely to be changed.

The basic turn-based empire management, planet mangment and map are the closest to done and are beaitful, with high production values in what is finished and a lot of fun.

If you are in this just for fun.. Play MOO2? Playing this game now is a lot of fun, but buying now is for people that just can't wait or enjoy being part of the development process.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So i've had this game for a few days now and ive played through 4 games. I love this type of game and am very happy to have it. If you enjoyed Endless Space you will like this game. Just keep in mind that this game is in early access so not everything will be implemented correctly or fully. I will keep my review to things that arent affected by EA.
The art style is very cool, and the tactical real time space battles are pretty awesome. would love to see real time land battles in an expansion pack eventually. The space lanes implementation is really fun and allows for strategic bottlenecking of enemies but I wouldn't be opposed to the possibiity to make them redundant with late or mid game tech research. I would most definately like to see an end to tutorial pop ups as they can get really annoying the more you play and learn the game. also i think a diplomatic feature that allows you to pressure another faction to make peace with a third party would be fantastic. Also alliances should have a similar feature so that you can make your allies, allies with each other.
TLDNR

overall I would recommend you buy this game only if you are patient enough to make it through the EA, as there are still many things that either need implementation or correction.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I bought this game on saturday and worked both days this weekend and I still have 50 hours in game at this point on Wednesday or almost. I am a Masters of Orion fan. This game and its copy cats I have played well for a long time.

When I go to load MoO3 my graphics are messed up so can't play it. But I like and enjoy what it had in freatures that this one doesn't. For example the way you could control spending on the different screens. I would ask that the game developers get an old laptop or desktop and go back to MoO3 and look it over.  MoO always beat out all the copy cats because of thier freatures and how it was controlled. I like the auto build option and how you can apply it planet by planet, so far the AI builds wrogn for a brand new planet instead of focusing on building up population and then defense it spends all it valuable first development time focus on making defenses. But this is the same way the empires nuild no matter the races. I have not spent enough time in this new release to see how its changed. But the AI is much tougher.

The ship to ship combat is worthless, and you get a huge OP fleet lost bc the controls are counter-intuitive. But the Auto is fun to watch. I only will do the ship to ship if I have a smaller fleet and know how to kill the other ships better than the AI. But in later parts I just do OP and let computer do it whiling focusing on overall big picture, and logistics of resupplying my fleets.

Having said that I enjoy this game AI and balancing that be tweeked but overall it is a good game for one of the copy cats But not worthy of the Masters of Orion name yet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My no reccomendation is based on the current state of the game, and could change.

MOO is a timeless classic.  Even MOO3 was startling for its excellence - its problems were early release and play style that encouraged excellent players but put off lesser players.  The current MOO version is an obvious attempt to bring forward the excellence of MOO2 and MOO3, perhaps wreitten smaller with less innovation in the technology tree, fewer races, less tidbits of detail, and and smaller horizons.

Right now it is pay for beta grade.  I never suggest player pay to play a game that is in essence a late alpha or early beta.  The game has serious flaws that prevent carry through an entire contest, and is essence a rough draft.  The rough draft though shows extreme promise.  Double the number of races, double the number of techs, work out the vario bugs in visual style and in combat, and get the combat rules to work (which of course, MOO3 never really did) and you have a game that would be one of the best of its type.  Add to that MacOS support - a game killer for many who have friends from the Mac side, and this could be the new standard for MOO>

That said, there are rumbles on the horizon.  The forums are filled with people who want the game to be a RTS or a nerfed experience.  Most of them never played MOO before.  If the DEVs listen to the very loud rapid fire posting of their minority, the game will die a death and be a waste of 30 bucks.

I would say revisit this in six months.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my inital review for the Early Access of Master of Orion.
Gametime: aprox 20 hours.

As a long time fan of Moo2 i am pleased to see that this game is way more Moo2 than Moo3.
It kind of reminds me of a crossover between Moo2 and Sins of a solar empire.

This game has a lot of potential to become great with some tweaks and polishing.
As it stand right now i think the game is unballanced in regards of research,
and the opponents are not much of a challenge. Frankly they are quite push-over.
Also combat is a little bit dull, its not engaging like the classic moo2 where you got to play your fleet.
Here it is real time combat and you have little control over whats happening. You can activate modules manually.
Also i miss being able to recruit ship officers and colony administrators for increased bonuses.
Would like to see this implemented, and perhaps with an xp system for the officers and administrators.

Some things that need adjusting and improving are Tool tips, Correct and updated stats on ship modules, Research,
Difficulty level, Sorting out misc bugs and strangely enough.. savegame size. My savegame folder now almost takes up 1gb of space.. with the largest save being 150mb.

There are also some bugs here and there, but nothing major, and a save and relog usualy resolves the issue.
If this is only on my client i do not know, my friend who purchased the game at the same time does not experience the same bugs as i do.

But i think the graphics looks great, races are pehaps a bit cartoony but i dont mind. Individual voice acting for each race, nice models and nice textures, nice cinematics. Engaging gameplay and it is easy to spend alot of time ingame.

To sum it up, the game as it stands right now has its flaws.. but it is an early access so what did you expect ?
Are the flaws game breaking ? no, not at all. The game is fully playable and quite enjoyable.
But i expect the game to become even greater with polishing and the correct tweaks.
Also i look forwards to more races and ingame content being implemented like higher difficulty and custom races.

• Should you buy it ? If you are a fan of the series i would say this is a must have. And buying into it right now you can give the developers feedback and help influence the game into becoming something great.
• Would i buy the game again ? Yes most deffinatly i would, even in early access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I would like to start by saying I wish there was an indifferent option for reviews. Because I'm on the fence about this game and my review. There are many things I like and many I don't. Overall, though, I feel like it's a pretty decent game and if you like 4X games you should check it out - just be prepared for some of the cheese.

Pros: Really polished graphics and effects, transitions, user interface, artwork - they spent a good amount of time making a refined, professional game that looks and feels good. The voice-over cast is amazing and they did a great job breathing life and character into the game. The gameplay is smooth and intuitive and allows simple management and stats without overloading you with information and details and micromanagement. Overall the FEEL of the game is excellent - one of the best-looking 4X games made to date. To summarize - the game is very pretty and gets a lot of geek cred for the voice actor fame. ♥♥♥♥in' space bears man!

Cons: Beauty is only skin deep. While there are some interestingly new minor elements to this game, it's pretty instantly recognizable with (and almost identical to) it's genre brethren like GalCiv3 and Endless Space. In fact, if anything, MoO:CtS is a more simplified version of the two other games with fewer options and a scaled-back depth of gameplay and management. What's especially bothersome is that the tech tree FEELS completely ripped-off from GalCiv3, down to the names of the techs themselves and the weapon systems (not to mention the cheesy newscasters announcing empire/galactic events of note). After all that, they added space bears with cheesy Russian accents - I love space bears but giving them a stupid name like Bulrathi" and giving them Russian accents... Oy 9.9

Summing it up: Despite its cons
date: I still enjoy playing the game and it's very pretty to look at. The lack of depth also means you can play through it faster than its 4X brethren. It's also a lot easier without FEELING like it is - you still feel like you're about to be overwhelmed at any moment by the opponents ganging up on you even if they never have the teeth to back it up. Is it worth $50? Well
recommended: since you get all of the other MoO games bundled in with that and you can still get a refreshing
hoursPlayed: new 4X gameplay experience for a good 20-30 hours
voteText: I'd say yes. YMMV!"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is an early access game. It's not complete by any standards. I have not played the older games, so I am able to come at this with fresh eyes. If you like the newer Civilization games, than this is Civilization in space. Combat is alright, I personally enjoy watching my ships battle against others. Ship customization is fine as it is, but I can say I would like to see maybe some more design choices and color choices. Diplomacy in all games is hard to balance, so expect the A.I. to make stupid requests (Oh? You're kicking out butt in this war? Alright, we'll go easy on you if you give us 1,000 credits and two colonies. No? Guess you'll have to conitnue to kill us!). Wish the A.I. was a bit more....aggresive, a bit more of a threat. Maybe it's the difficulty I'm playing under. Heroes would be a cool addition, but maybe in an expansion.  Overall, this is still an early access (First update should be soon right?), so don't expect a full game. If you played the older ones, this is apparently not MOO2....whatever that means.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Plays for 200+ turns in one sitting
Attempts to fight the guardian of Orion
Loses entire fleet in 30 seconds
Loses game a few turns later
Immediately restarts

In all honesty this game is great. The voice acting is spot on, the graphics (aside from leader backgrounds for some reason) are beautiful, the music is spellbinding. Honestly, I am impressed by how good this game is, even at such an early state. Yes, a few races are still MIA, and yes the combat needs to be fleshed out a bit more, but the game at its core is still super strong, and the game is well set to become the best MoO to date.

I've really enjoyed what I've played so far.  This is definitely still an Early Access game though.  There are all sorts of features not implemented yet or aren't working very well.  I only experienced one crash so far.

I don't know why so many people are giving 'no' recommendations, and are complaining about stuff not working.  Like it says in the big blue box at the top, this is an early access game.  I bought in early so I could get the previous MoO games.  If you're unsure, wait for the full release.  I plan to switch to MoO2 until the full release after I conquer the galaxy in my current game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is good.  No, it's not a clone of MOO2.  I have friends that enjoy this game that were MOO2 fanatics.  We all love the game and it's progressing nicely.  Tactical combat is getting better, you can always pause the game and issue orders as well.  Don't expect this game to be MOO2, it's an introduction for a wider audience with beautiful graphics, full voice overs and a pretty amazing amount of work already done.

I loathe reading the negative posts out here.  The game is STILL BEING DEVELOPED AND IS EVER CHANGING.  It's in an early enough stage for hundreds if not thousands of changes to happen.  The DEVS listen to their fan base!  The game is going to rock at some point, have no doubt.  It's already pretty damn good now.

You can scroll through all the other technical posts out there to your hearts content, so I'm just giving my impressions of the state and future of the game.

Most of the haters out there are MOO2 purists.  Nothing wrong with that, but this game isn't MOO2.  If you don't like it, don't bash it, attempt to appreciate the fact that it is a very good game and getting better all the time.  Take it for what it is.  Aside from that, check out Stellaris, launcing Monday May 9th.  It looks amazing, just in a more text driven and less polished way.  Galaxies have 1,000 stars to explore and it might just kill lesser computer systems (even though the engine is old and runs on DX9).  If it's not buggy as ♥♥♥♥, I will pick that one up too.  Then I will have two amazing games in my library.

Peace out people

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Masters of Orion 2 was on my list of top 10 games for their era.
I think the people building this iteration of master of Orion want to recapture the magic of Masters of Orion 2, but bring things up to speed with the technology we have at hand. In that this game looks spot on. I do not see vast innovations in gameplay either, but this is better than changing what obviously worked so well.

I have but one real complaint thus far, and because this is early access I won't get too upset about it just yet.
I am playing on my MacBook Pro Retina on OS X Yosemite. It runs great, until for no discernable reason the game crashes. It crashes in a way that won't let me window out to Force Quit. I can move my mouse but not select anything, so I have to do an Emergency cold reboot. I was enjoying the game very much, until this issue.

I have a request. Although I love the races in this game. I hope users will be able to use mods one day to load in new names for races, upload new alien race pictures, perhaps even upload new ship models into the races in play, if they feel like playing  private games with other well established science fiction milieus. Flexibility will make the game even more popular in certain circles.

Anyways keep up the good work. I am going to be positive  and trust that the Mac crash problem will be resolved soon.

Now someone please make a new version of Masters of Magic!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nTaking into account that this game is still in its alpha phase, I am loving it. I spend most of my time playing Space games and the few that truly keep my interest over the ages have been Endless Space and Master of Orion 2. The flaws that made Master of Orion 3 boring, dull, and overly time consuming effort spent in the micro managing department are gone. I was skeptical over the introduction of space lanes but after playing the game for a bit I feel that the space lanes do nothing to hamper the gameplay and the ability to construct Military stations at the entrance of these lanes that you control give me a feeling of security. No longer can random races travel my territory if I do not have an Open border policy with them. The space battles are solid and for what it is( Alpha ) I am overly pleased. I cannot wait to see what else comes from this finally ressurected behemoth of a franchise

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game has been improved as of patch 42.4.1. The A.I. has been improved, which was my major gripe on relase. Along with that, the game has been made more challenging with the release of harder A.I. difficulty settings.

The game is still incomplete, missing key features such as espionage and two races, however the developers clearly care about the game and are constantly working toward fixing bugs, balancing and finishing up the missing content.

The game in its current state is enjoyable. Therefore, I would recommend any strat-fans to purchase and play Master Of Orion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Clearly on the bleeding edge of early access at this point. I had to start a game over because a non-existent ship kept demanding orders. Computer isn't aggressive enough, there are too many worlds so there's no competition.

I think they did the right thing with planets this time around, as oppsed to the MOO3 disaster. I like that there's more yield in the first good spots.

Star lanes are bad. Part of the reason diplomacy isn't what it was in MOO2 (which wasn't what it was in MOO1) is that you rarely border more than two other empires. None of the craziness of five-ways wars in the middle of the map.

I miss the cheap ships of MOO1: dangit, I want to have 10,000 fighters in a stack.

Played it a lot trying to like it. Still too early.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll preface this little review, I've played a fair bit now but I am a die hard Moo II fan this new reinvention doesn't quiet live up to the legacy, although the game looks and sounds great.

Fair to say it is in Early Access and it''s definitely not finished yet, if you're after a polished experience wait a little while longer. I've not had EA2 get stuck or prevent me from playing though. and just two CTD. The dev's seem to be touching thing's up nicely, I'll still give it more time.

I've enjoyed what I've played but unfortunately I don't think it has the depth Moo II has.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ok to start off i loved Moo 2, Moo 3.... well it was ok. Moo 3 had some good ideas but it failed on refinement... horribly.
this game so far needs more refinement aswell but thats why its in early access but i also dont care for some of the changes from moo 2 to here...
star lanes for instance, aswell as unstable star lanes" that box you in untill you get half way through the tech tree
date:
i for one liked the fact that you had could bypass an empires outer planets and attack their inner worlds it added a chance to bypass the enemy fleet if they didnt pay close enough attention and now we have no ship distance restrictions as long as you can get through those red star lanes

now the combat system..... combat..... personally i think its terrible as of current build
all fleets have a combat strength rating which is visible to all.... so you can see exactly what your opponents have which boils engadgments down to a very basic if you have a higher number than the enemy you attack
recommended: if not retreat and build up/upgrade your ships
hoursPlayed:
repeat untill you win... even the guardian of orion you can see its combat raiting plain as day.... of all the ships which should have their strength hidden it should be the guardian
for those who claim theres a stratagy element to it because its real time combat.... no there really isnt other than keep your small ships back for a bit because they move alot faster than the larger ones and will die like the cannon fodder they are too early... but then they refuse to sit still so you end up having to micro manage your smaller ships moving back and forth untill the right time to bring them up closer to your larger ships for the attack to start

shurly the races are being done well? ..... nope
granted i havent played matches with them all yet but so far its a definate nope. the psylons i remember being an awesome race.... so what did they do to them in this game?  in the animations they made their advisor into the stereotypical highschool geek whos afraid to speak. and with that in mind in the game play they have a tendancy to rule their corner of the galaxy with ease
voteText: crushing any race unlucky enough to be stuck in the same boxed in star lane segment as them\n\nthe diplomacy.... needs to be implemented still... aside from the ai making demands of you and then declairing war when you refuse
helpfulPercent: there is none but they have announced that its going to be worked on (thank god
votesHelpful:
if i hear the murshan hiss at me for refusing to give them money ill snap and declare war on them first)

so long story short i prefered playing moo 3 to this stage of its progress... wait until its out of early access to buy and keep an eye on it because it does have potential to be great..... great flop or great success is yet to be seen


***Update***

so after a couple of patches the game is comming together nicely and im changing my recommendation to a yes

you do need to understand its still a work in progress
votesTotal: like the diplomacy while it has been worked on
votesFunny: still needs more work done such as: it would be nice to throw out a counter offer (within reason) to avoid the "refused to trade with us" penalty to rep because an offer of 60 credits/bc/gc/whatever they call the currency is too low for technology that requires multiple turns to research\n\nthe only other part of the game i dislike is their choice for voice actors for some of the leaders/advisors such as the silicoid advisor.... for those who dont know
commentsCount: the silicoids are a race of rock people (essentally) and their advisor is a soft voiced person it just dosnt seem to fit
column16:
but i gotta say they did a good job on most of the leaders voices

now you may be noticing im only saying what i dont like about the game... thats mainly because the rest is either in the awesome catagory or at least the acceptable because its early access

and i guess now that ive said that i should give some examples.... this game is the most stable early access ive seen and i have gotten into several... a few that i regret too... not this one though

the real time ship combat has been greatly improved you can set individual ships engadgement distances so you can customise your ships to have specializations such as long range missile support or a close range brawler. you can also set all ships movement speeds so your frigates and destroyers no longer rush way ahead of the titans that they are cannon fodder for.

i cant confirm it but the unstable star lanes seem to be less frequent than before

TLDR: was ok

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love it. It is just like playing the original Orion, with a few changes here and there to update it. The original races are there, with a promise of more to come, but I do wish one could customize a race like Orion 2. Seeing this is an early release, there are surprisingly few issues with it, A few things that need work is that I've not been able to terraform a volcanic planet yet, I hope this comes in future updates. Also, the Guardian is too weak, I beat it with just 4 battleships, losing only one. The guardian should be a lot more powerful. Another thing that would add to the game (and be true to the original if I remember correctly, if that wasn't MoO2) is that once you grow more powerful Orion may launch surprise attacks at any race unbalancing the universe too much. But I really miss the turn-based combats, I hope they will be next to be included.

As of the latest update, if you choose a larger planet than normal you get the gravity penalty to all production, halving food, production and science. The penalty is too big to compensate for the late game profit of having a large or huge planet. This is reason enough to change the rating from positive to negative, since the starting planet (even by biologial reasoning) should always be considered normal gravity, with no exceptions; after all that is the gravity the race you choose is used to.

Another update is that custom races are available, but cannot be saved, still a miss from the developers. And finally, older games cannot be replayed or continued, so there's no backward compatibility between game versions.

With the laterst updates I'm starting to question de competence of the game designers, and whether they should be replaced... after all the last updates made the game so much worse that the rating changed from positive to negative, and I'm considering a refund. In any case, I will change my review on other sites to do not buy" now."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing MOO, looks pretty good, however it's missing some stuff (not because it's EA, but basic stuff like):

+ Battles look nice
+ The game overall looks very polished
+ production / food / research system looks very cool, if you assign people, your overall productivity / worker decreases. Very logical and new, a like it a lot
+ Research tree is pretty long and nice. I also Like the fact that at somepoint you have to choose between 2 or 3 of the real applications of a certain theory. Much better designed than choosing from two fields imho.
+ Colony screen looks good, I would however like to have the pollution shown in the empire screen. There are couple of bugs there with the notifications of pollution, it tells you you have a polluted planed and it jumps to another planet, I guess it will be fixed.
+espionage... nice concept
+ trade treaties... good way to make some extra money if you have the capital

- I would like to have a trade concept where you can transport food. There is an export / import system but It's minimalistic
- Something that a lot of 4xgames do not understand. Food is not the main driver of reproduction in a colony. Food is only a show stopper (law of the minimum), if you don't have it, but lots of food does not mean more people. Look at Europe... lots of food, but stagnation.
- Ground battles suck, building ground military sucks, I want to be able to control the pace of building my ground forces
- Cannot transport people from the empire screen... hello? MACRO much?
- AI may still need some improvement, but they already did a big step
